    <item>
      <title>Wild Beasts review – heart-racing, poignant farewell from indie originals</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/wild-beasts-review-heart-racing-poignant-farewell-from-indie-originals</link>
      <description><p><strong>Hammersmith Apollo, London<br></strong>This glorious final gig by the fearless Cumbrians almost makes you wish bands would break up more often</p><p>Of all the 2000s indie bands you wish would see the writing on the wall, <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/wild-beasts">Wild Beasts</a> are not one of them. Last September, <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/sep/25/wild-beasts-split-up">the Cumbrian four-piece announced</a> that, after releasing five albums, it was “time to leave this orbit”. You’d praise their self-awareness (critics agreed their last album, 2016’s <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/aug/07/wild-beasts-boy-king-review">Boy King</a>, was their least remarkable) if they weren’t leaving such a gaping hole in the scene. It’s hard to think of another band who has so compellingly revelled and recoiled at masculinity, deconstructed and delighted in sexuality.</p><p>When bands split, fans are usually privy to the wreckage rather than the last rites. The knowledge that tonight’s gig is the last time they will ever perform these songs (<a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/sep/25/wild-beasts-split-up">Wild Beasts have sworn they won’t reunite</a>) makes every moment unbearably poignant. Their manifold lyrics about loss and regret become gut punches. “All we want is to feel that feeling again,” Hayden Thorpe croons on Mecca. Too right, say a crowd that gives each song a Viking-style send-off.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/wild-beasts-review-heart-racing-poignant-farewell-from-indie-originals">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Morrissey review – aloof, obnoxious and proudly provocative</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/morrissey-review-hydro-glasgow</link>
      <description><p><strong>Hydro, Glasgow<br></strong>For someone who often seems determined to alienate his fanbase, Morrissey has a knack for intuiting exactly what they want</p><p>If all publicity really is good publicity then <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/nov/16/morrissey-low-in-high-school-review-old-greatness-spoiled-by-ugliness-and-spite">Morrissey’s Low in High School </a>campaign should be judged a tremendous success. While promoting his 11th solo album he zoomed off-piste during a BBC 6 Music session to float conspiracy theories about the <a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/evfwhn/live/cwz5d4">Ukip leadership election</a> and engaged in a tetchy war of words with a German newspaper that published an interview in which he appeared to defend <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-42338456">Kevin Spacey</a>. Alongside these self-sabotaging lows, there have also been some highs. Los Angeles, the stronghold of his ardent US fanbase, declared 10 November to be <a href="http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-morrissey-hollywood-bowl-review-20171111-story.html]">Morrissey Day in his honour</a>.</p><p>For those still loyal to the Smiths godhead, like the sizeable crowd in this Glasgow arena, dealing with a certain amount of aloof obnoxiousness simply seems par for the course. Even some of the rolling videos that serve as preamble to this gig feel like trolling. Alongside clips of the New York Dolls, Germaine Greer and the Four Tops, there is extended footage of Russian pop duo Tatu performing their shrill cover of How Soon is Now? on Top of the Pops in 2003.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/morrissey-review-hydro-glasgow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘Harassment is systemic’: why white roses won't change the music industry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/music-industry-sexual-harassment-brit-awards-white-roses</link>
      <description><p>As the Brit awards respond to #MeToo with flowers, insiders say gestures are not enough</p><p>After sartorial support was shown for the Time’s Up and #MeToo movements at the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/gallery/2018/jan/08/golden-globes-fashion-highlights-from-the-red-carpet-in-pictures">Golden Globes</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/jan/29/white-roses-and-black-velvet-the-grammys-red-carpet">the Grammys</a>, the Brit awards <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/14/brit-awards-ask-guests-to-wear-white-rose-pins-to-support-metoo">are following suit</a>. The awards’ organising body, the British Phonographic Industry, has invited artists and guests attending the 2018 ceremony to wear a white rose pin “as a symbol of solidarity” – although the memo doesn’t specify the cause.</p><p>The Guardian understands the BPI consulted industry figures on how to acknowledge the issue of sexual harassment and abuse in the arts. The body ultimately partnered with <a href="https://twitter.com/voicesinent?lang=en-gb">Voices in Entertainment</a>, the American collective of female executives that asked artists to wear white roses to the Grammys. “If the Brit awards can help shine a light on such a sensitive topic, our hope is that it will ultimately help,” says the awards’ chair, Jason Iley.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/music-industry-sexual-harassment-brit-awards-white-roses">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>One to watch: The Orielles</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/the-orielles-one-to-watch-indie-band</link>
      <description><p>This film-loving indie trio find their inspiration in the 80s – just don’t talk to them about love</p><p>There may eventually be a day when young bands stop making jangly, melodic surf pop with girl-boy vocals, a DIY aesthetic and slightly surreal lyrics, but that time is not yet nigh. Enter <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/mar/20/new-band-of-the-week-the-orielles-no-144">the Orielles</a>. A few years ago in their native Halifax, sisters Esmé Dee and Sidonie B Hand-Halford met guitarist Henry Carlyle Wade at a house party, clicked, and formed a band the following day.</p><p>Their gauzy, 80s-inspired sound may well be partly derived from the Hand-Halfords’ father being in 80s noir-indie band <a href="http://www.thetrainset.co.uk/the-band/">Train Set</a>, but the trio have made it their own, going off piste with eight-minute <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5IeeCaHz01g">psych-garage wig-outs</a> that would not sound at odds in a San Francisco dive bar.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/the-orielles-one-to-watch-indie-band">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Everything Is Recorded: Everything Is Recorded By Richard Russell review – mogul music with a stellar cast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/everything-is-recorded-review-mogul-music-with-a-stellar-cast-richard-russell-xl</link>
      <description><p>As head of XL, Richard Russell shaped UK music for three decades. His own debut release finds its voice in many singers</p><p>Imagine, for a moment, being the man who signed Adele. You run a label – XL – home to mavericks as diverse as Dizzee Rascal, Radiohead and Arca, and you produce records by your heroes – Gil Scott-Heron, Bobby Womack – in what one might laughably call your spare time. By many people’s definitions, you’d be about as fulfilled, three-dimensional and jammy a human as there is. In 2015, your net worth was guessed at £75m, but your impact on British music is harder to calculate.</p><p>Then imagine being paralysed. One minute, you’re putting out <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jan/24/scott-heron-new-here">Gil Scott-Heron’s final album</a>. And then – insert an obscure sound effect here, the kind that you collect – you’re laid low by <a href="https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/guillain-barre-syndrome/">Guillain-Barré syndrome</a>, an autoimmune disease that attacks the nervous system. It’s 2013, you’re in hospital, and you can just about twiddle your fingers. Geoff Barrow, on behalf of Portishead, sends you a dinky synth – a <a href="https://www.critterandguitari.com/products/pocket-piano">pocket piano by Critter &amp; Guitari</a> to be precise – to retrain your synapses and stop you going mad. You can’t help but read Russell’s paralysis as one of those defining moments that would map the road ahead, if he could ever get his motor skills back.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/everything-is-recorded-review-mogul-music-with-a-stellar-cast-richard-russell-xl">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>UK's first live music census finds small venues struggling</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/uks-first-live-music-census-finds-small-venues-struggling</link>
      <description><p>Survey highlights venues’ problems with business rates and noise restrictions</p><p>The UK’s first live music census has found that a third of Britain’s small venues outside of London are fighting to survive in the face of high business rates and noise restrictions.</p><p>Of almost 200 small music venues (with a capacity of up to 350 people) surveyed, 33% reported that increases in business rates had an “extreme, strong or moderate” impact on their existence in the past 12 months. One medium-sized venue (351 – 650 capacity) reported their rateable value quadrupling from £17,500 to £72,000.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/uks-first-live-music-census-finds-small-venues-struggling">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Matt Bellamy and Dominic Howard joined us to chat about their favourite conspiracy theories, secret side projects and what exactly Thought Contagion is</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-16T13:05:29.073Z">1.05pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Thanks guys, we loved your questions. - DH</p><p>Really enjoyed talking to you and will continue on Twitter later. - MB</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-16T13:04:54.621Z">1.04pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p><a href="https://profile.theguardian.com/user/id/100002796">LewisF2001</a> asks:</p><p><em>Chris, what’s your favourite young and upcoming band?</em></p><p>Chris isn't here sadly, but I like that band Judah and the Lion. I heard some artist, I think a bit of a solo act, called Grandson, the other day, and it sounds a bit like weird, heavier Twenty One Pilots, Nine Inch Nails kinda thing, sounds cool. He's literally just released a few singles. - DH</p><p>I quite like the look of that band that played the NME awards, Pale Waves - that was the first time I'd heard of them. - MB</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/live/2018/feb/13/muse-webchat-thought-contagion-matt-bellamy-dominic-howard">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Readers recommend playlist: songs about rendezvous</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/08/readers-recommend-playlist-songs-about-rendezvous</link>
      <description><p>Artists ready to meet up for this week’s date include Basement Jaxx, Canned Heat, Frank Zappa and the Rolling Stones<br></p><p><strong>Here is this week’s playlist – songs picked by a reader from hundreds of suggestions on <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/01/readers-recommend-share-your-songs-about-rendezvous">last week’s callout</a>. Thanks for taking part. Read more about how our weekly series works at the end of the piece.</strong></p><p>New York is a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/12/21/upshot/Mapping-the-Shadows-of-New-York-City.html">city of shadows</a>, concrete mountains and canyons, street noise. But there are high-rise havens to be had. On the roof the air is clear and at night the stars put on a show. Our protagonist asks his baby to join him – to rendezvous – and in sharing a hidden paradise the <strong>Drifters</strong>’ Up on the Roof (Gerry Goffin and Carole King at their finest) starts this week’s playlist. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/08/readers-recommend-playlist-songs-about-rendezvous">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>

      <title>Time travel, amphetamines and Virgin Trains: the story of the Fall in 20 songs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/25/time-travel-amphetamines-and-virgin-trains-the-story-of-the-fall-in-20-songs</link>
      <description><p>Mark E Smith’s group of psychedelic post-punks rank as one of the most visionary, singular British bands of all time. From their krautrock beginnings to their still-brutal late period, here is the definitive primer to their work</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/24/mark-e-smith-lead-singer-with-the-fall-dies-aged-60">Mark E Smith, founder and lead singer with the Fall, dies aged 60</a></li><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/24/mark-e-smith-the-fall">Appreciation – Legend of the Fall: Mark E Smith kept swinging to the end</a></li></ul><p>Some of the Fall’s early oeuvre paid lip service to prevalent musical trends: it’s not too much of a stretch to imagine Industrial Estate or Psycho Mafia passing for punk rock. But the B-side of their debut single, Bingo-Master’s Break-Out!, made clear that the Fall saw punk merely as the opening of a door, through which a unique musical vision, utterly unpalatable 18 months previously, might pass.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/25/time-travel-amphetamines-and-virgin-trains-the-story-of-the-fall-in-20-songs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will Young: ‘Our podcast is a queer Woman's Hour’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/will-young-our-podcast-is-a-queer-womans-hour-homo-sapiens</link>
      <description><p>Homo Sapiens is a frank and funny podcast hosted by Will Young and film director Chris Sweeney. Mark Smith joins them on tour in the north of England</p><p>Will Young hasn’t been to a sexual health clinic before so our hosts at Manchester’s <a href="http://lgbt.foundation/">LGBT Foundation</a>, a community charity near the city’s gay village, are keen to impress upon him that sandwiches and cakes do not come as standard for its service users. “They’re posh ones from the deli – not the Greggs stuff we usually lay on for visitors,” remarks Peter Brampton, a sparky sexual health project leader.</p><p>Young and his film director friend Chris Sweeney are here as part of their tour of the north of England for the second season of their rose-tinted yet highly successful podcast <a href="http://homosapienspodcast.com/"><em>Homo Sapiens</em></a>. The first series heard the pair chatting to LGBTQ+ luminaries, such as the trans actor <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/aug/22/rebecca-root-interview-not-fighting-myself-any-more">Rebecca Root</a>, actor <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/bisi-alimi">Bisi Alimi</a> (who caused fury in his native Nigeria by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2016/feb/09/bisi-alimi-on-lgbt-rights-in-nigeria-it-may-take-60-years-but-we-have-to-start-now">coming out</a> on television) and human rights activist <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/petertatchell">Peter Tatchell</a>. A visit to his tiny London flat was poignant, with Young somehow managing to convey the depths of Tatchell’s personal sacrifice with fretful asides about the dusty clutter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/will-young-our-podcast-is-a-queer-womans-hour-homo-sapiens">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sébastien Tellier and Dita Von Teese: 'Everything we do is glamour'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/sebastien-tellier-and-dita-von-teese-everything-we-do-is-glamour</link>
      <description><p>He’s the Frenchest man since Gainsbourg, she’s the world’s premier burlesque star. Together, Sebastian Tellier and Dita Von Teese have made an unlikely electronic pop collaboration worthy of Serge himself </p><p>Seated together in an upscale London bar, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/oct/11/mika-dita-von-teese">Dita Von Teese</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/may/30/sebastien-tellier-interview">Sébastien Tellier</a> are a study in contrasts. She is immaculately turned out and looks, well, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/dec/13/dita-von-teese-your-beauty-mark-the-ultimate-guide-to-eccentric-glamour-digested-read">exactly like Dita Von Teese</a>, from her perfectly coiffed jet-black hair to her seamed stockings and high heels. He is the picture of bohemian dishevelment: wild beard, straggly hair, a large glass of wine in one hand and packet of fags and a lighter in the other.</p><p>She exudes a very US kind of retro glamour, and talks about her transformation from Heather Sweet, a blond, machinist’s daughter from Michigan, into the world’s best-known burlesque star in terms of the American dream: “Like the big Hollywood makeover, a girl would come from a Midwestern town and she’d look like an ordinary girl, and then suddenly she’d be otherworldly – I wanted to do that in real life.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/sebastien-tellier-and-dita-von-teese-everything-we-do-is-glamour">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The surreal success of MGMT: 'I assumed it would all go away. Like it was all a dream'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/feb/10/the-surreal-success-of-mgmt-i-assumed-it-would-all-go-away-like-it-was-all-a-dream</link>
      <description><p>Ten years after their indie pop anthem Kids, Ben Goldwasser and Andrew VanWyngarden are back and working with Beyonce’s producer. But can they stop the self-sabotage?</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/mgmt"> MGMT</a> were huge. The duo graced 2008 with three festival classics: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B9dSYgd5Elk">Time to Pretend </a>provided them with a manifesto, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fe4EK4HSPkI">Kids</a> an anthem and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MmZexg8sxyk">Electric Feel</a> a floorfiller. Their synth-swathed astral indie seemed a logical progression from nu-rave’s MDMA epiphanies to tuning into the cosmos on LSD. They were part of a group of acts, which included Yeasayer, Passion Pit and Santogold, who went from Brooklyn warehouse infamy to suddenly proper on-David-Letterman famous. Along the way, they inspired a Gucci runway show and made hippy headbands a thing.</p><p>Behind the scenes, however, the relationship between the two members was of complementary opposites: the analytical Ben Goldwasser and the free-spirited Andrew VanWyngarden. “It’s strange,” Simon O’Connor of fellow Brooklynites Amazing Baby told Rolling Stone in 2010. “There would be weeks where they didn’t even speak to each other. Then they’d spend a whole day writing in Ben’s room, and then go their separate ways again. They’re like a married couple that has really good sex but that’s it.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/feb/10/the-surreal-success-of-mgmt-i-assumed-it-would-all-go-away-like-it-was-all-a-dream">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Chainsmokers review - pyrotechnic rallying slogans and theatrical self-loathing</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/15/the-chainsmokers-review-alexandra-palace-london</link>
      <description><p><strong>Alexandra Palace, London</strong><br>Gimmicks, grand entrances and pop-cultural gags inhabit the DJ duo’s universe, where vague grievances attain epic proportions</p><p>Each pop era needs a critical piñata to embody all its horrifying afflictions, but few offer quite so large a target as the Chainsmokers. Derided first for their <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kdemFfbS5H0">sexist videos</a>, then their <a href="https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/magazine-feature/7510387/the-chainsmokers-billboard-cover-closer">preposterous interviews</a>, the duo have nonetheless insinuated themselves into the culture’s fabric. To their credit, the New Yorkers’ breakthrough in 2014 had substance, ushering a pensive sensibility into the rapidly expiring EDM movement. Their palette soon broadened – they’ve now settled into a sort of pop-house for soulful bros – but not as quickly as their audience, which has <a href="https://twitter.com/TheChainsmokers/status/941060976677408768?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&amp;ref_url=http%3A%2F%2Fnow100fm.com%2Fthe-chainsmokers-2017-spotify-streaming%2F">generated more song streams</a> than the planet has inhabitants.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/nov/03/chainsmokers-american-idol-mark-ronson-closer">The Chainsmokers on feuding with Mark Ronson and writing 2016’s biggest hit</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/15/the-chainsmokers-review-alexandra-palace-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Simple Minds review – a jumbo celebration of past and present glories</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/14/simple-minds-review-barrowland-glasgow-jim-kerr</link>
      <description><p><strong>Barrowland, Glasgow<br></strong>A less blokey lineup sounds modern and impressively energised, while Jim Kerr sings with innate confidence</p><p>In a crammed hometown venue you suspect they could fill twice over with friends and family alone, <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/simple-minds">Simple Minds</a> are throwing a party. Their current UK mini-tour marks both 40 years since their first ever gig – at a long-defunct discotheque in Glasgow city centre – and their 17th album, Walk Between Worlds, recently cracking the top five.</p><p>The result is a jumbo-sized celebration of past and present glories sprawling enough to include the new record played in its entirety, two mercifully brief on-stage interviews with a local DJ and a snowballing cavalcade of standouts from a career that has zigzagged between electronica-infused post-punk and strident, stadium-filling anthems. They have even brought along a customised disco ball.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/14/simple-minds-review-barrowland-glasgow-jim-kerr">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Glen Hansard review – raw wounds, soulful swagger and Trump Sr</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/11/glen-hansard-review-royal-festival-hall-london-southbank</link>
      <description><p><strong>Royal Festival Hall, London<br></strong>Hansard’s Southbank debut showed an artist relishing the freedom of switching genres – from Stax-y bluster to Woody Guthrie protest</p><p>Making his Royal Festival Hall debut, the Oscar and Grammy-award winner Glen Hansard is strumming an acoustic guitar and singing a cod-reggae ditty about bananas. It’s a surreal highlight of a two-hour show that’s a snapshot of an artist in flux, caught between picking at his wounded heart and throwing slinky dance moves to his blossoming southern soul. </p><p>Backed by a 12-piece band including brass and strings, Hansard’s powerful voice, whether raw with passion or tender with regret, shines above arrangements both chillingly sparse and bursting with horn stamps and swagger. Often singing a capella, Hansard forgoes the mic for a startling rendition of <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=elpwI15CClI">Grace Beneath the Pines</a> that’s as much sermon as song, but throws himself into the Stax-y bluster of <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=INKq3n1rEsY">Roll on Slow</a>, from his latest album, Between Two Shores, with equal abandon.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/11/glen-hansard-review-royal-festival-hall-london-southbank">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kendrick Lamar review – rap's regal genius delivers a cliche-free knockout</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/08/kendrick-lamar-review-dublin</link>
      <description><p><strong>Dublin 3Arena </strong><br>The megastar sparks arena-sized bedlam on his own terms: with a breathtaking show that lets his music do the talking</p><p>A man garlanded with every honour going, from Grammy awards to a spot in Time magazine’s 100 most influential people in the world, Kendrick Lamar nevertheless seems a little taken aback by the response to his arrival in Dublin. “I heard y’all painted a picture of me on a wall,” he says. “No one’s ever done that before.” Indeed they had: no sooner had he landed than <a draggable="true" href="http://www.dailyedge.ie/kendrick-lamar-2-3838948-Feb2018/?utm_source=shortlink">a vast mural of him appeared</a>, towering over Aungier Street. Meanwhile, in the venue, the audience’s adoration is both rowdily intense and so word-perfect that when Lamar stops rapping and cuts the music during <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tvTRZJ-4EyI">Humble</a>, they carry an entire verse without flagging. </p><p>In fairness, they have a lot to be excited about. Lamar’s live show avoids most hip-hop gig cliches: at no point are all the ladies in the house required to scream, nor are we subjected to the reliable lowlight that is the lengthy demonstration of the DJ’s turntable skills. Instead, there’s a performance that is simultaneously understated and spectacular. Aside from the occasional brief appearance of a dancer or a man dressed as a ninja, there’s nothing to look at except for Lamar and a succession of films that seem more like edgy arthouse fare than anything you’d usually see at a sellout arena show.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/08/kendrick-lamar-review-dublin">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jorja Smith review - smoky new voice in UK soul</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/07/jorja-smith-review-liquid-room-edinburgh</link>
      <description><p><strong>Liquid Room, Edinburgh</strong><br>On the opening night of her sellout tour, the singer and Stormzy collaborator reveals a talent for personal pop</p><p>‘You have to dance with me!” grins <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jul/23/jorja-smith-review-homegrown-r-and-b-new-voice-electric-brixton">Jorja Smith</a>, half pleading, with the only flicker of shyness she has shown all evening. When the bass kicks in, Edinburgh’s unruly, adoring audience need no persuasion.</p><p>It’s the first night of Smith’s sellout UK tour, two years after she shared her first track on SoundCloud. Since then, the 20-year-old from Walsall has gained heady accolades and celebrity supporters with one EP and a handful of singles. That first song, Blue Lights, written for a school project on post-colonialism in UK grime, sampled Dizzee Rascal’s Sirens and showed a spellbinding talent for sleek, inventive soul. A month later, Drake played it on his Ovo Sound Radio and became one of her loudest champions. Shortlisted for the BBC’s Sound of 2017 award, winner of the Brits critics’ choice award in December, and due to feature on Kendrick Lamar’s soundtrack for Marvel’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/06/black-panther-review-marvel-wakanda-chadwick-boseman">Black Panther</a>, Smith’s ascension to pop stardom has been secured by her strong sense of self.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/07/jorja-smith-review-liquid-room-edinburgh">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Rejjie Snow: Dear Annie review - Irish rapper's loverman reinvention</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/15/rejjie-snow-dear-annie-album-review-irish-rapper</link>
      <description><p>Though it’s hard to hear his Dublin roots on this long-awaited debut, Snow’s conversion to soft-voiced Brooklyn seducer is convincing and stylish</p><p>A couple of years ago, as part of a social media charm offensive <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/commentisfree/2016/may/16/azealia-banks-apologizes-for-racist-rant-about-zayn-malik">that also involved hurling racist abuse</a> at One Direction’s Zayn Malik, <a href="https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7350371/azealia-banks-continues-trashing-beyonce-lemonade-shes-not-an-artist">accusing Beyoncé of trying to “capitalise on blackness”</a> and telling a 14-year-old Disney star that her mother could boost the girl’s career by “sucking dick”, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/azealia-banks">Azealia Banks</a> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/azealia-banks-axed-uk-music-festival-zayn-malik-twitter">took on the entire UK rap scene</a>, allegedly calling it “a disgrace to rap culture in general”. Forget Drake’s boosting of Skepta and Giggs, she suggested: “No American rappers are looking to the UK for any sort of tips. Be as angry as you want to be. But facts are facts.” However wrongheaded she may have been about the scene’s quality, it’s hard not to think she might have had a point about American hip-hop’s parochialism. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/may/02/sugarhill-gang-how-we-made-rappers-delight-interview">Almost 40 years since </a><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/may/02/sugarhill-gang-how-we-made-rappers-delight-interview">Rapper’s Delight</a> was released, hip-hop has reached middle age without really breaking the rule that rappers from outside the US never make it there, unless you count Canadians and émigrés: Britain’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/slick-rick">Slick Rick</a> and Australia’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/iggy-azalea">Iggy Azalea</a> both moved to the US years before their careers began.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/ng-interactive/2017/mar/06/sign-up-for-the-sleeve-notes-email">Sign up for the Sleeve Notes email</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/15/rejjie-snow-dear-annie-album-review-irish-rapper">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US girls: In a Poem Unlimited review – joyous pop meets protest music</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/us-girls-in-a-poem-unlimited-review-4ad</link>
      <description><p>(4AD)</p><p>‘It so happens that, right now, a lot of the things I’ve been talking about for the last 10 years of doing this project are all coming to a head in the mainstream,” <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/oct/19/us-girls-meghan-remy-halt-free">Meghan Remy – AKA US Girls</a> – said recently. The #MeToo campaign and other movements have placed issues such as domestic violence and male abuse of power at the heart of the political agenda and into everyday conversation in ways Remy couldn’t have imagined when she was making albums for a succession of US indie labels. So the second work for 4AD by the Toronto-based, Illinois-born artist arrives with perfect timing, and tackles difficult issues with her most accessible music so far. </p><p>The mix of classic 60s girl group and disco-era Blondie is so gloriously celebratory that it’s not always obvious that she is singing about something as harrowing as domestic violence. That subject rears its ugly head most vividly in the innocuously titled track Incidental Boogie, which unflinchingly explores abuse and denial (“No marks and no evidence” and “I feel brutalised, but closer to him”) over fizzing sci-fi funk. Remy isn’t the first artist to musically sweeten a bitter lyrical pill, but her collaboration with Toronto musical collective the Cosmic Range (who include her husband, Maximilian Turnbull) makes an effective vehicle for sharp ruminations on topics such as factory work hell (Rage of Plastics), violent revenge on an abuser (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YkIvuGYGqA">Velvet 4 Sale</a>) and her disappointment with American politics (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XtGb5NiGBjc">Mad As Hell</a>).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/us-girls-in-a-poem-unlimited-review-4ad">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>(Heavenly Recordings)</p><p></p><p></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/the-orielles-silver-dollar-moment-review-heavenly-recordings">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Car Seat Headrest: Twin Fantasy (Face to Face) review – striking remake with extra oomph</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/car-seat-headrest-twin-fantasy-face-to-face-review-will-toledo</link>
      <description><p>(Matador)</p><p>“Give me Frank Ocean’s voice and James Brown’s stage presence,” sings <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/25/indie-sad-lads-car-seat-headrest-alex-g-whitney-palace-winter-kevin-morby">Will Toledo</a> on Cute Thing, highlighting his own shortcomings – he has a tendency to sing in a tone that suggests he’s been given pesto for dinner for the seventh day in a row and he really, really wanted sausages, and a performing persona that suggests he’d rather be digging out his eyeballs with teaspoons – as well as the fact that he’s generated a fervent following with neither of those gifts. </p><p>Toledo is an intriguing figure: his 11th album is a rerecording of his sixth, given extra oomph and proper production now that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/22/car-seat-headrest-review-100-club-london-will-toledo">Car Seat Headrest is a muscular, exciting, rock band</a>, rather than only him making music in his bedroom. There are some changes – Nervous Young Inhumans has a new set of lyrics – but in the main, this is about pulling the album into sharper focus. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/car-seat-headrest-twin-fantasy-face-to-face-review-will-toledo">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Nipsey Hussle: Victory Lap review – west coast rap at its finest</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/nipsey-hussle-victory-lap-review-atlantic</link>
      <description><p>(Atlantic)</p><p>In what might be rap’s longest promo campaign, G-funk revivalist Nipsey Hussle has been announcing the imminent arrival of his debut album, Victory Lap, since 2012. The album release date has shifted from 2013 to 2014 to 2016, to 2018, while Hussle has been making his name from a steady stream of mixtapes (including 2013’s Crenshaw, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jan/20/nipsey-hussle-rapper-mailbox-money-1000-dollars">which he sold at $100 a pop</a>, netting $100,000 in the process). The wait has been so long that many fans had consigned Victory Lap to the same graveyard of unreleased west coast classics as <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/may/27/dr-dre-2-night-kendrick-lamar-jeremih-detox">Dr Dre’s Detox album</a> – now Hussle has finally deemed it worthy to be released, expectations are understandably high. </p><p>In Victory Lap’s best moments, Hussle effortlessly claims his place as crown prince of G-funk’s new school. On tracks such as <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_4LsQ_kdLh0">Rap Niggas</a> and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QM9xgHibvzM">Last Time That I Checc’d</a> (where he’s joined by fellow LA revivalist YG) his brags rasp as hoarse and righteous as a man in the middle of a three-day bender, riding beats built from oozing bass swagger and slinking Compton synths, as brash and gleeful as peak-era <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/nwa">NWA</a>. It’s visceral west coast rap at its unapologetic finest, as Hussle refreshes cliches of unstoppable prowess with the conviction of a true believer. Elsewhere, there are saggy moments. Tracks are padded out with meandering instrumental outros – presumably to lend the album the cinematic gravitas a six-year gestation period demands; instead, they seem self-indulgent. At least half the album feels like padding, and there’s nothing with the sheer rage and power of his verses on 2016 anti-Trump classic FDT. Perhaps Hussle isn’t quite ready for the victory lap just yet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/nipsey-hussle-victory-lap-review-atlantic">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>MGMT: Little Dark Age review – synthpop pranksters get serious for a change</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/08/mgmt-little-dark-age-album-review</link>
      <description><p>After two albums of wilfully awkward music seemingly designed to lose them fans, the duo return with some unironically gorgeous melodies and a dash of hallucinogenic weirdness</p><p>What do you do after you’ve committed career suicide? It’s a question you suspect may have hung heavy over Ben Goldwasser and Andrew VanWyngarden, better known as MGMT. Ten years ago, their debut album, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/dec/09/mgmt-oracular-spectacular">Oracular Spectacular</a>, catapulted them to fame: they were nominated for Grammys, their songs were covered by everyone from Katy Perry to Weezer, their music was sampled by Frank Ocean and Beyoncé. But fame was something the duo didn’t seem keen on, perhaps because, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/apr/08/mgmt-congratulations-oracular-spectacular">in their telling</a>, MGMT was originally intended as a joke: a couple of smartarsed college kids making ironically poppy music with lyrics mocking rock excesses. (“I’ll move to Paris, shoot some heroin and fuck with the stars,” go the lyrics of breakout hit <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B9dSYgd5Elk">Time to Pretend</a>.) The joke got taken seriously to the tune of 1m sales. <br></p><p>And so they did something about it. Congratulations (2010) sounded less like their debut’s synthy psych-pop than a strain of obscure early-80s British indie that wonkily Xeroxed 60s psychedelia for the troubled Thatcher era: the Television Personalities, the Cleaners from Venus, the Deep Freeze Mice. Clearly, not even the most vociferous fan of the last band’s oeuvre (Hitler’s Knees, My Geraniums Are Bulletproof, Peter Smith Is a Banana, etc) would claim this as a recipe for success. So it proved: Congratulations sold 66,000 copies in its first week and 11,000 in the next 18 months. There were even fewer takers for its <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/sep/19/mgmt-mgmt-review">eponymous 2013 successor</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/08/mgmt-little-dark-age-album-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Black Panther soundtrack review - Kendrick Lamar's Superfly moment</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/09/black-panther-soundtrack-review-kendrick-lamar</link>
      <description><p>The rapper’s knotty nihilism shines through as he curates an all-star album featuring the Weeknd and James Blake</p><p>Film soundtracks are often <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/mar/10/2">critically acclaimed</a>, they’re occasionally <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/shortcuts/2018/feb/07/big-choruses-greatest-showman-soundtrack-top-of-charts-hugh-jackman">big sellers</a>, they sometimes even <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/jul/09/movie-soundtracks-pulp-fiction-boyhood-coldplay-chuck-berry">insinuate themselves into popular culture</a> in the same way that a zeitgeisty studio album might. But they rarely attract the kind of advanced publicity afforded the soundtrack to Black Panther. For some time now, the web has been awash with news stories anticipating its release. The most recent of these revealed that Kendrick Lamar had <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/05/kendrick-lamar-produces-marvel-black-panther-soundtrack">got the job</a> of curator. On reading said scoop, it became apparent that the revelation was: he had a meeting about it.</p><p>That kind of thing tells you something about the hysterical pitch at which the internet conducts itself, but also tells you something about Kendrick Lamar, an artist in the midst of a creative streak so hot that being seen as his equal is the kind of thing other rappers brag about. “Not even Kendrick can humble me,” boasts Schoolboy Q at one point on the Black Panther soundtrack. Lamar is so revered that even his more ephemeral releases are greeted with elation: if the guy’s so good that he can put out a collection of <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/mar/04/kendrik-lamar-untitled-unmastered-first-listen-review-alexis-petridis">untitled demos and outtakes</a> that’s better than many artists’ main albums, why shouldn’t people get excited about a film soundtrack created under his aegis?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/09/black-panther-soundtrack-review-kendrick-lamar">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brigid Mae Power: The Two Worlds review – steely songs about abuse and recovery</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/09/brigid-mae-power-the-two-worlds-review-tomkins-square</link>
      <description><p>(Tompkins Square)</p><p>When The Observer gave four stars to the then-unknown Brigid Mae Power’s 2016 <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/26/brigid-mae-power-album-singer-songwriter-review">self-titled debut</a>, Kitty Empire observed a lingering malevolence tingeing the Irish artist’s saturnine hymnals, writing: “We don’t know what [she] has been through.” <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/19/brigid-mae-power-my-metoo-post-was-the-greatest-gift-i-gave-myself">Now we do</a>. In the late 2000s, Power lived in New York, trapped in an abusive relationship, which she <a href="https://www.tumblr.com/safe-mode?url=http://brigidpowerryce.tumblr.com/post/167317287457/metoo-part-1">recently detailed</a> in support of the #MeToo movement. She moved back to rural Ireland, had a child and wound up a single mother, her wages barely covering childcare. So in 2013, she quit her job and decided she might as well keep gigging. A brief run of good fortune led to her signing with cult American primitive label Tompkins Square and releasing her debut – a salt-washed set of droning laments that recalled <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/apr/25/soundtrack-my-life-sharon-van-etten-righteous-brothers-lemonheads">Sharon Van Etten</a>’s rougher early work.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/19/brigid-mae-power-my-metoo-post-was-the-greatest-gift-i-gave-myself">Brigid Mae Power: ‘My #MeToo post was the greatest gift I gave myself’</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/09/brigid-mae-power-the-two-worlds-review-tomkins-square">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Frank Ocean: the most talked-about man in music</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/jul/21/frank-ocean-guardian-exclusive-interview</link>
      <description>His new album Channel Orange was rushed out a week early to rave reviews, then he made headlines worldwide by blogging about his sexuality. 'I wanted to wake up without this freakin' boulder on my chest,' he says in this Guardian exclusive<p>Frank Ocean has had quite the week. "Yes," he says, smiling, with a barely perceptible shake of the head, as if in mild disbelief. Then he nods: "Yes. But also awesome." Two things have contributed to making his week awesome. There's the surprise release of his second album <a href="http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2012/jul/11/frank-ocean-channel-orange-review1" title="">Channel Orange</a>, a week before it was officially planned, which met with rabidly enthusiastic reviews comparing his idiosyncratic, narrative-heavy reimagining of soul and R&amp;B to <a href="http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/prince" title="">Prince</a> and Stevie Wonder. Then there was the post on <a href="http://www.tumblr.com/tagged/frank+ocean" title="">Tumblr</a> in which he told, beautifully, the story of falling in love for the first time, with a man. "I don't know what happens now, and that's alrite," he wrote.</p><p>You can understand why Ocean might be feeling a little stunned. He's suddenly the most talked-about man in music, though he hasn't yet done much of the talking himself. He shuffles into a dressing room behind Vancouver's Commodore Ballroom nursing a herbal tea, and plays with it nervously, a hoodie wrapped around his neck like a scarf, before politely shaking my hand, all the time avoiding eye contact. He's 24, relatively new to all of this, and suddenly the world wants to know his business.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/jul/21/frank-ocean-guardian-exclusive-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The Californian music festival will also feature the Weeknd, David Byrne, Cardi B and dozens more pop and rap stars</p><p>Coachella, the two-weekend Californian event that traditionally kicks off the summer’s festival season, has announced the lineup for its 2018 edition.</p><p>Beyoncé will headline on April 14 and 21, in her first live shows since her Formation world tour in 2016. The R&amp;B star took 2017 off from live performance after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2017/jul/14/beyonce-and-the-instagram-that-gained-5m-likes-and-counting">giving birth to her twins</a> Rumi and Sir, and the Coachella announcement will further fuel rumours she is gearing up to release new material.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/03/coachella-2018-lineup-announced-beyonce-eminem-the-weeknd">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A-wokening: is pop culture’s political surge a movement or a moment?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/feb/17/pop-cultures-re-awokening-is-this-political-shift-a-movement-or-moment</link>
      <description><p>Social consciousness is a key part of creativity in 2018, from Kendrick Lamar’s Damn to this year’s celebrity Big Brother. But is it more than just a trend?<br></p><p>A quick quiz: what do these have in common? <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/katy-perry">Katy Perry</a>’s “purposeful pop”; the reboots of <a href="http://variety.com/2018/tv/news/party-of-five-reboot-freeform-1202668286/">Party of Five</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jul/10/ghostbusters-review-paul-feigs-female-reboot-melissa-mccarthy-kristen-wiig">Ghostbusters</a>; <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/macklemore">Macklemore</a>; that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2017/apr/06/pepsi-race-luther-king-kendall-jenner-lindsay-lohan">Kendall Jenner Pepsi ad</a>; and, most recently, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M4vnmgZLA8s">Justin Timberlake’s video for his song Supplies</a>, where the star surveys the ills of today’s world on TV screens before heading off to party at what looks like an Occupy-chic rave.</p><p>The answer is: they are all, apparently, woke.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/feb/17/pop-cultures-re-awokening-is-this-political-shift-a-movement-or-moment">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jóhann Jóhannsson: the late Icelandic composer who made loss sublime</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/11/johann-johannsson-the-late-icelandic-composer-who-made-loss-sublime</link>
      <description><p>Best known for his film scores, Jóhannsson’s earlier electronic and classical work confronted existential horror</p><p>Despite its regular use during inspiring moments on nature documentaries, Jóhann Jóhannsson never made music that’s particularly easy listening on its own – and Lord, it’s tough listening to him now. </p><p>After hearing of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/10/theory-of-everything-composer-johann-johannsson-dies-at-48">his death</a>, I found my notes from when <a href="http://www.theartsdesk.com/classical-music/j%C3%B3hann-j%C3%B3hannsson-hauschka-dustin-ohalloran-barbican">I saw him in London at the Barbican</a> in 2012: “He makes music for endings, shut-down mines, obsolete mainframe computers and failed utopias ... the notes fade away, the stories have already finished, everything ends.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/11/johann-johannsson-the-late-icelandic-composer-who-made-loss-sublime">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Khalid review – smooth Generation Z karaoke session</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/15/khalid-review-hammersmith-apollo-london</link>
      <description><p><strong>Hammersmith Apollo, London</strong><br>The crowd knew every word on the opening UK night of the Texan R&amp;B singer’s Americana-laden tour</p><p>Khalid’s success has Generation Z stamped all over it. Not only did the 20-year-old Texan R&amp;B singer emerge online seemingly fully formed, he got his big break when the Kardashians’ Kylie Jenner used a snippet of his track Location on a Snapchat video. Two years on, his debut album has sold over a million copies in the US, he’s been nominated for five Grammys, toured with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/lorde">Lorde</a> and had an EDM crossover hit with Marshmello. Indeed, by the time his name popped up on the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/nov/27/bbc-sound-of-2018-longlist-sigrid-not3s">BBC’s Sound of 2018</a> poll for breaking acts at the end of last year, he seemed almost too established to be included.<br><br>The young crowd joining him for the opening night of his first UK headline tour know every word. On opener American Teen – also the album title – a combination of their volume plus deafening feedback means it’s difficult to hear Khalid’s vocals. To hammer home the Americana theme, there are two cheerleaders twerking on stage, and obvious footage of stars and stripes on a screen.</p><p>It’s often easy to forget that this is a concert and not a karaoke session tailored for selfie-taking: as well as the star-spangled banner, we’re treated to a projection of a highway, a montage of pictures of Khalid, a ferris wheel and more. It’s reminiscent of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/lana-del-rey">Lana Del Rey</a>’s initial shtick, which seemed more like nostalgic pastiche than an artistic identity before she developed the aesthetic later on.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/15/khalid-review-hammersmith-apollo-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Polar prize: Metallica to receive 'Nobel prize of music'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/14/metallica-polar-music-prize-nobel-sweden-stockholm</link>
      <description><p>Heavy metal band will accept prestigious £90,000 award at a ceremony in Stockholm in June</p><p>Metallica have been named recipients of Sweden’s Polar prize, considered one of music’s most prestigious awards. The <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/metallica">Los Angeles four-piece</a> are the first metal band to receive the honour, which has previously gone to acts including <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/jonimitchell">Joni Mitchell</a>, <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/paulmccartney">Paul McCartney</a> and Chuck Berry.</p><p>Drummer Lars Ulrich said: “It puts us in very distinguished company. It’s a great validation of everything that Metallica have done over the last 35 years. At the same time, we feel like we’re in our prime, with a lot of good years ahead of us.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/14/metallica-polar-music-prize-nobel-sweden-stockholm">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I started something I couldn't finish: the Smiths reunion that wasn't</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/30/the-smiths-reunion-mike-joyce-craig-gannon-morrissey-johnny-marr</link>
      <description><p>Three former members of the indie band were due to reunite for a series of gigs that fell apart as soon as they were announced. Mike Joyce and Craig Gannon explain why they tried to make it happen</p><p>There’s no panic on the streets of Salford, but there is something in the cold Monday morning air. A few days earlier, keen fans spotted something intriguing on former Smiths drummer Mike Joyce’s social media: a series of <a href="https://twitter.com/mikejoycedrums/status/954399499258138625">images</a> bearing a musical note and Joyce’s surname, along with those of bassist Andy Rourke and short-lived “fifth Smith”, guitarist and sometime bassist Craig Gannon.</p><p>Was it possible? A Smiths reunion in the offing? Albeit one with no mention of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/morrissey">Morrissey</a> or lead guitarist <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/johnnymarr">Johnny Marr</a>. The news was formally announced in the early hours of 22 January: three-fifths of one of the most influential bands in British pop history were reuniting for a series of classical concerts, reinterpreting the Smiths’ hits alongside an orchestra. Come lunchtime, Joyce and Gannon were going to spill the beans.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/30/the-smiths-reunion-mike-joyce-craig-gannon-morrissey-johnny-marr">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Form 696 is gone – so why is clubland still hostile to black Londoners?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/31/form-696-is-gone-so-why-is-clubland-still-hostile-to-black-londoners</link>
      <description><p>Met police form 696, which once required club promotors to detail the ethnicity of their clientele, has been removed. But discrimination is cropping up in other ways</p><p>In 2005, form 696 was created by London’s Metropolitan police: a risk-assessment document that required the city’s nightclub promoters to give details of the events they planned to host, including a description of the style of music that would be played, and the target audience it would be played to, including their ethnicity. It drew heavy criticism for its racist tone, and was seen as discriminating against grime, rap and other underground black genres. Despite the ethnicity and music style clauses being removed in 2008, it was still dogged by accusations of racial bias, and the form was banished altogether in November last year by Mayor of London Sadiq Khan.</p><p> But as with most institutional racism in the UK, the reality is that it will take far more than the scrapping of a piece of bureaucracy to change clubbing for London’s black people; with gentrification creeping through east and south London, black promoters are still discriminated against. “You often have to go to quite a few venues before you even have a shortlist,” says Jojo Sonubi, founder of <a href="https://www.instagram.com/rec.ess/">Recess</a>, a night aimed at black millennials. “Even after that, there’s a sense that you still have to convince owners that you’re not going to be a rowdy bunch. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/31/form-696-is-gone-so-why-is-clubland-still-hostile-to-black-londoners">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/clubs">Clubbing</category>

    <item>
      <title>Brix Smith Start on Mark E Smith: 'He shook up the snow globe every day'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/26/brix-smith-start-mark-e-smith-the-fall</link>
      <description><p>Mark E Smith’s former bandmate and wife talks about of his ‘multidimensional’ creativity, his channelling of chaos, and the sausage rolls at their wedding</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/26/an-agent-of-chaos-fuelled-by-fire-stars-memories-of-mark-e-smith">‘An agent of chaos, fuelled by fire’: stars’ memories of Mark E Smith</a></li></ul><p>I feel so honoured to have worked with, and been a partner with, somebody so singularly talented and groundbreaking and free-thinking – off the scale of what people understand free-thinking is. He came at everything from multidimensions and odd angles, outside every box. Forget about pushing the envelope – there was no envelope. Mark had this theory that there were seven original people in the world and that everybody else is a slate of one of those seven. I have to say that Mark was absolutely one of those seven.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/24/mark-e-smith-lead-singer-with-the-fall-dies-aged-60">Mark E Smith, founder and lead singer with the Fall, dies aged 60</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/26/brix-smith-start-mark-e-smith-the-fall">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Stetsons, beards and good, honest sweat: why pop stars are going back to basics</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/jan/20/stetsons-beards-and-good-honest-sweat-why-pop-stars-are-going-back-to-basics</link>
      <description><p>Country and Americana have become shorthand for mainstream musicians who want to mature. Justin Timberlake is the latest to join the ranch</p><p>One of the new year’s biggest surprises has been the appearance of a pensive son of the soil by the name of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/justin-timberlake">Justin Timberlake</a>. In a short teaser video announcing his fifth solo album, Man of the Woods, the former ‘<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/oct/01/nsync-will-never-reunite">NSync</a> star went a-wanderin’ through forests, fields, mountains and streams, lookin’ fer answers to this big ol’ riddle we call life. Bearded and rugged, he looked like a man who wouldn’t think twice about climbing into the body of a dead horse for warmth. This on-the-nose rebrand inspired rather more hilarity than Timberlake might have expected, resembling as it did a commercial for a cologne that smells of cattle, woodsmoke and good, honest sweat.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/jan/05/justin-timberlake-filthy-review">Justin Timberlake: Filthy review – comeback single channels Prince for grown-up funk masterpiece</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2018/jan/20/stetsons-beards-and-good-honest-sweat-why-pop-stars-are-going-back-to-basics">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Blurred Lines to New Rules: how sex in pop has changed for ever</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/18/from-blurred-lines-to-new-rules-how-sex-in-pop-has-changed-for-ever</link>
      <description><p>The charts were once dominated by pornified raunch, but in an era of identity politics and empowered women, a new kind of sexuality is emerging in pop – and warming cyberspace</p><p>When Robin Thicke and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/pharrellwilliams">Pharrell</a> released Blurred Lines on 26 March 2013, they had no idea (or claimed not to) that it would kickstart a debate about rape culture and misogyny in pop . The outraged response to its suggestive lyrics – particularly the refrain “I know you want it” – permanently changed the standards to which pop is held, and the way in which pop itself deals with sex.</p><p>That is not to say that sex has vanished from pop since the controversy. Jason Derulo and Bruno Mars are no strangers to objectification; ex-boybanders such as the former <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/one-direction">One Direction</a> members are still breaking with their clean-cut pasts by letting you know in song exactly how much sex they’re having; while Brit awards nominee <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/may/25/rapper-j-hus-i-was-doughnut-hustler-common-sense">J Hus</a> cackles in the face of good taste. In 2016, Ariana Grande released a classic of the form in the admirably brazen Side to Side, about the inability to walk straight after a long night at the coal face.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/18/from-blurred-lines-to-new-rules-how-sex-in-pop-has-changed-for-ever">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Remake, remodel: what makes musicians rerecord old albums?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/18/what-makes-musicians-rerecord-old-albums-shins-car-seat-headrest</link>
      <description><p>The Shins and Car Seat Headrest are the latest bands to indulge in rerecording their earlier work. Is it money for old rope, or a chance at artistic liberation?</p><p>The next month brings not one but two instances of bands rerecording entire albums. This Friday, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/the-shins">the Shins</a> release The Worm’s Heart, a “flipped” version of last year’s Heartworms, in which the running order is reversed and each song performed in a different style. On 16 February, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/22/car-seat-headrest-review-100-club-london-will-toledo">Car Seat Headrest</a> follow suit with a new version of 2011’s Twin Fantasy, an emo lo-fi album in which the then 19-year-old Will Toledo dissected his toxic love life.</p><p>The latter case is easy to understand. What ended up being a touchstone album for CSH’s fans was originally recorded by Toledo alone on a laptop, and it sounds like it. Its power comes from its intimacy, the sense of performer speaking directly to listener, almost unmediated. But since then Car Seat Headrest have become a proper band, and Toledo apparently had it written into his deal with Matador that he could revisit the album. “It was never a finished work,” he has said, “and it wasn’t until last year that I figured out how to finish it.” The comparison between the old and new album is like that between a demo and a finished record: everything is punchier, bigger, brought into focus. Things are different in places (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3NPATRzaF00">Nervous Young Inhumans</a> has a new set of lyrics), but it’s not a reimagining so much as a clarifying.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jan/18/what-makes-musicians-rerecord-old-albums-shins-car-seat-headrest">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jessie J's bid to win a Chinese talent show is the best career move</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/why-jessie-j-bid-to-win-a-chinese-talent-show-is-the-best-career-move-shes-ever-made</link>
      <description><p>The platinum selling pop singer recently signed up to compete in China’s Singer - a bizarre yet safe space in which she can be smothered in praise</p><p>Jessie J’s career launched with the bright embers of a blunt, fizzing away at the start of her debut video <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pOf3kYtwASo">Do It Like a Dude</a>. That song went platinum, as did her debut album, four times over. J quickly transformed into a household name, appearing as a judge on The Voice. But then things started to go tits up. Her second album was a relative flop and the press turned on her for being too full of herself. She complained that people didn’t “appreciate” her voice in the UK, and said she was going to move to the US where, she promised the Daily Mail in a 2014 interview, she was taken seriously as a singer.</p><p>That briefly worked, with <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0HDdjwpPM3Y">Bang Bang</a>, her collaboration with Ariana Grande and Nicki Minaj, becoming a huge hit. But while her fellow collaborators went on to better things, J’s career stalled again. To make up the difference, she signed up to a string of promotional deals, doing ads for McDonald’s, Cadbury Dairy Milk and Tuc cheese crackers.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/why-jessie-j-bid-to-win-a-chinese-talent-show-is-the-best-career-move-shes-ever-made">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>On my radar: Tracey Thorn’s cultural highlights</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/on-my-radar-tracey-thorn-cultural-highlights</link>
      <description><p>The singer and author on 70s clubland, the photography of Andreas Gursky and a musical about a Sheffield drag queen</p><p><strong>Born in Hertfordshire in 1962, Tracey Thorn is one half of </strong><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/jun/17/everything-but-girl-early-albums-interview"><strong>Everything But the Girl</strong></a><strong>. She formed the band in Hull with her now husband, Ben Watt, and they released their debut album,<em> Eden</em>, in 1984; they have been on a hiatus since 1999. In 2013, she published her memoir, </strong><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/feb/10/bedsit-disco-queen-thorn-review"><strong><em>Bedsit Disco Queen: How I Grew Up and Tried to Be a Pop Star</em></strong></a><strong>, followed in 2015 by </strong><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/08/naked-at-the-albert-hall-tracey-thorn-review-eloquent"><strong><em>Naked at the Albert Hall</em></strong></a><strong>. Her fifth solo album, <em>Record</em>, is released on Caroline International on 2 March. </strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/on-my-radar-tracey-thorn-cultural-highlights">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/tracey-thorn">Tracey Thorn</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/disco">Disco</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/photography">Photography</category>
      <pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 10:00:41 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/on-my-radar-tracey-thorn-cultural-highlights</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/6b3be0c6263c906caa1d6f0b239cf46fb273f154/0_736_4904_2942/master/4904.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=bb16c4af228dd68442e4c813bb195337">

    <item>
      <title>I'm With Her: ‘We’re about camaraderie, not Hillary’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/im-with-her-band-interview-bluegrass-music-aoife-odonovan-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz</link>
      <description><p>Women are expected to take a back seat in the arch-conservative world of bluegrass music. But Aoife O’Donovan, Sara Watkins and Sarah Jarosz refused to be sidelined – even after Hillary Clinton ‘borrowed’ their band name</p><p><a href="https://www.imwithherband.com/">I’m With Her</a> had been playing together for 18 months when <a href="https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CZscPjmWIAIHVy4.jpg">Hillary Clinton unwittingly commandeered their band name</a>. “It wasn’t the worst thing in the world,” says Aoife O’Donovan. “If that campaign slogan had been on the other side, we might have rethought the situation.”</p><p>Then again, a band called Make America Great Again would probably do well in the archly conservative bluegrass world that these women frequent. The Hillary connection, not so much. “I’m sure it’ll be a turn-off for some people,” says <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jan/30/sara-watkins-fiddle-interview">Sara Watkins</a>, the other member of the trio alongside <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/jan/30/aoife-odonovan-dingwalls-review">O’Donovan</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/19/sarah-jarosz-undercurrent-review-classy-americana">Sarah Jarosz</a>. “But that’s not what the band is about – we’re not making a political statement. It’s a celebration of each other. It’s camaraderie.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/im-with-her-band-interview-bluegrass-music-aoife-odonovan-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gaetano Donizetti opera lost for 200 years set for London premiere</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/gaetano-donizetti-ange-de-nisida-lost-opera-rara-london-premiere</link>
      <description>Eight years of detective work will culminate in July’s first performance of ‘amazing’ tragedy by great Italian composer<p>A lost opera by one of the great Italian composers is to have its world premiere in London almost 180 years after it was written.</p><p>Gaetano Donizetti was a leading figure in 19th-century Italian music, along with Giuseppe Verdi and Vincenzo Bellini. His most famous work, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/oct/31/lucia-di-lammermoor-donizetti-katie-mitchell-lisette-oropesa-review-royal-opera-house"><em>Lucia di Lammermoor</em></a>, written in 1835, is seen as one of the great European operas. But <em>L’Ange de Nisida</em> (<em>The Angel of Nisida</em>) – composed in the late 1830s after he moved to work in Paris – never saw the light of day. It was written for the city’s Théâtre de la Renaissance, but the company went bankrupt before it was premiered.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/gaetano-donizetti-ange-de-nisida-lost-opera-rara-london-premiere">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fischerspoon: Sir review – not worth the nine-year wait</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/fischerspooner-sir-music-review-damien-morris</link>
      <description><p>(Ultra)</p><p><em> </em>Fischerspooner were key to the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2007/jul/11/electroclashisnoflashinth">electroclash movement</a> that briefly twinned Europe’s gay capitals and New York almost 20 years ago. <a href="https://fischerspooner.com/">The American duo</a> have finally resurfaced with their first album in nine years, produced by REM’s Michael Stipe. In an unfortunate choice of phrase for British readers, <em>W</em> magazine described frontman Casey Spooner’s voyage of discovery after ending a long relationship as “bumming around Europe”. Sadly, the album doesn’t sound half as much fun as the journey. </p><p>Yes, Stipe’s work is often impressively feral, pitting harsh junkyard-dog synths against mountains of reverb. Yet the songs are largely weak, paralysed by unresolved tension. They lack the explosive catharsis that made Fischerspooner’s very first single Emerge an underground classic, or the radio-friendly arrangements of their best album <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2005/apr/08/popandrock.shopping1"><em>Odyssey</em></a><em>.</em> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/fischerspooner-sir-music-review-damien-morris">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Troye Sivan: ‘There’s power in living openly while being gay’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/troye-sivan-theres-power-in-living-openly-while-being-gay</link>
      <description><p>With his Madonna referencing music and porn star-featuring video, the vlogger turned musician is redefining what it is to be a male pop star </p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/troye-sivan">Troye Sivan</a> is pop’s greatest hope for the future. His horny and hedonistic new single <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k5TqNsr6YuQ">My My My!</a> is already the year’s best, and its accompanying video – all heaving torsos, wet-look hair and more strutting than a Victoria’s Secret runway show – screams “superstar” in big neon letters. In person, 22-year-old Sivan, like that other modern-day superstar <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/lorde">Lorde</a>, is a softly spoken, hugely intelligent over-thinker. But the Troye Sivan of My My My! is the epitome of what 2018 needs: a star sashaying in a billowing shirt, frayed denim and tight white vest, singing a synthpop explosion of a song about sex from a male perspective that doesn’t make you want to bathe in bleach immediately after hearing it. While Justin Timberlake wonders what his lady friend is going to do “with all that meat” (pop it in the freezer?) on comeback single <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gA-NDZb29I4">Filthy</a>, and Jason Derulo literally equates women with animals in his video for <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nNA9ru2Ox5o">Tip Toe</a>, My My My! is a universal, celebratory rush saturated in playful lust.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/troye-sivan-theres-power-in-living-openly-while-being-gay">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Wild Beasts: Last Night All My Dreams Came True review – an anticlimactic exit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/wild-beasts-last-night-all-my-dreams-came-true-review</link>
      <description><p>(Domino Documents)</p><p>Last September, Leeds-based four-piece <a href="http://wild-beasts.co.uk/">Wild Beasts</a> announced their amicable split. Recorded last summer at RAK Studios in London and released the weekend of their farewell gig, this final album is the second on Domino’s live-in-the-studio Documents imprint (the first was <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/nov/15/julia-holter-review-shepherds-bush-empire-london">Julia Holter</a>’s <em>In the Same Room</em>). For the most part, the versions here are refinements of the originals rather than wholesale overhauls. This Is Our Lot still owes a debt to the Cure’s Lullaby; A Simple Beautiful Truth continues to benefit from its economy. The exception is The Devil’s Palace, which seamlessly splices together The Devil’s Crayon and Palace. </p><p>However, while this collection gives a good oversight of a consistently interesting career, it’s telling that the songs that leap out here – All the King’s Men from 2009’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/dec/17/albums-2009-wild-beasts-two-dancers"><em>Two Dancers</em></a> ; an incredibly potent Wanderlust from 2014’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/23/wild-beasts-present-tense-review"><em>Present Tense</em></a> – are their older ones. Given that, it’s unfortunate that <em>Last Night… </em>draws rather so heavily on material from 2016’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/aug/07/wild-beasts-boy-king-review"><em>Boy King</em></a>, the first Wild Beasts album on which memorable moments were in short supply. It all adds up to a slightly anticlimactic exit for a great band.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/wild-beasts-last-night-all-my-dreams-came-true-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gilles Peterson: 'The boundary between club culture and jazz is finally breaking'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/gilles-peterson-club-culture-jazz-nubya-garcia-nightports-shabaka-hutchings</link>
      <description><p>There’s an exciting DIY mindset in the UK live scene that recalls the buzz around jazz when I DJed at Dingwalls in the 80s </p><p>It’s really exciting to see so much new, influential British music being made by jazz artists. As I write this, I’m listening to a white label of <a href="https://matthewbourne.bandcamp.com/album/nightports-w-matthew-bourne">Matthew Bourne and Nightports</a>: a solo jazz pianist reimagined by an experimental, Hull-based production group. Simply the fact that this could be released on vinyl in 2018 fills me with positivity about where the music scene is at.<br><br>For me as a DJ, it’s especially exciting to see the new connections being made between club culture and live jazz. It’s a link I’ve been trying to make, in one way or another, for the past 30 years. Now more than ever before, it feels as if that boundary is finally being broken down.</p><p>Lots of these artists don’t attach the same kind of baggage to the word 'jazz' as previous generations.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/16/gilles-peterson-club-culture-jazz-nubya-garcia-nightports-shabaka-hutchings">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Cosmik debris: Frank Zappa's son reveals details of hologram tour</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/06/the-bizarre-world-of-frank-zappa-hologram-tour-announced-ahmet</link>
      <description><p>Using unseen footage from the 1970s, the tour will take to the road later this year, with Zappa’s long-term band members</p><p>Frank Zappa’s son Ahmet Zappa has revealed details of a forthcoming tour helmed by a hologram of the late experimental rock star. The Bizarre World of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/frank-zappa">Frank Zappa</a>, based on previously unseen performance footage from the early 1970s, will begin touring later this year.</p><p>The tour will feature Zappa’s long-term band members Ray White, Mike Keneally, Scott Thunes, Robert Martin and Joe “Vaultmeister” Travers. Guest appearances are planned from Steve Vai, Warren Cuccurullo, Arthur Barrow, Ed Mann and Vinnie Colaiuta, plus Ian Underwood and Napoleon Murphy Brock from the Mothers of Invention. Other names are yet to be announced.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/06/the-bizarre-world-of-frank-zappa-hologram-tour-announced-ahmet">Continue reading...</a></description>
